segments.text: Quietly, as if to herself, eyes closed, forgetting for a moment the other soldiers lying in their beds beside her.
She sought comfort for her broken heart and began to softly sing to herself.
Try to remember the kind of September.
Try to remember that September when life flowed slowly and everything was so calm and peaceful.
try to remember that September, when only the weeping willow was crying.
Life proceeded gently, and dreams were kept by the pillow, and if you remember, follow the memories.

She didn't know how she suddenly started singing that wonderful song, but since then, every evening, when the commander announced lights out and darkness would descend on the large room full of soldiers,
Ruchel, her new friend in the bed next to her, would ask her to sing that song.
Quietly, in complete darkness, to the backdrop of silence, they would almost whisper the chorus, follow, follow.
It became like a lullaby.
This song embedded itself in her heart from all the amazing songs she learned from Pole, the singer, songs whose lyrics were like poems and filled her heart and soul during those hard days.
often painting a picture of her life in that period, clinging to memories, knowing that the most beautiful memories would be the ones she best preserved.
This song also knows that in the end, it's the heart that remembers and guides you to follow the memories.
One evening, they saw the shadows of the commanders standing by their rooms door, almost secretly, listening in amazement to the odd group of novices singing acapella, follow, follow.
She wondered whether Pole even knew what an important layer she added to her life.

how her fingers learned almost by themselves to pluck the repertoire of charming songs she gathered, how much peace and rest they provided her when she played or hummed them in her heart, unknowingly becoming the soundtrack of her life.
Where is she now?
It's been over a year since she saw her.
She left for Paris and vanished from their lives suddenly.
She had days filled with longing, not always knowing what for.
She missed her pink house, missed Rolf, and so much missed her mother.
She understood she couldn't live her life in the shadow of memories, but knew that some deserved a place of honor in what she had grown and would grow to be.
While others she hoped to push far behind walls, hoping they'd stay there forever.
Those memories were hidden inside her, emerging suddenly due to something she saw, felt or smelled, wrapping her instantly.
Sometimes she couldn't believe how precisely the heart remembers how many of these memories she would carry with her forever.
shaping who she was, cushioning her essence.
She remembered Lucy's scent.
She could never forget her fragrance, a delicate scent of Madame Rocha's perfume.

She remembered that day, a few weeks after her passing, when she entered her room to find something, opened the right side of the closet, which had been closed for months, and was enveloped by mom's scent.
At first, she didn't know where it came from.
She thought maybe it lingered on the hanging clothes.
Then her gaze landed on the bottom shelf, just above the floor.
From it, empty perfume bottles peaked out.
She knelt and began to withdraw the bottles one by one.
About 30 empty perfume bottles were stored at the bottom of the closet.
Each still held the last drops of perfume, wrapping the closet in that scent, momentarily bringing her mother back to her.
Leora sat on the floor, arranging the bottles and rose in a cardboard box she had brought with her, and moved them to her room.
This way, Lucy could envelop her in her scent.
Yosef tried to convince her to throw the empty bottles away, fearing she wouldn't cope.
But she was determined.
For two and a half years,
Until that day, she packed her life into two small boxes, and among her few belongings, she packed five empty bottles of Madame Rochasse to remember her mother's scent.
Everything was so intense and so fast.
The days were packed to the brim and utterly exhausting, which was a good thing.
And if that wasn't enough, immediately after basic training, she continued to a squad leader's course, completing it three months later.
Now, as she promised Zavik from Carmella, she made her way to Ashkelon to report to him with her new ranks and the instructor's cord that a friend braided for her from parachute cords.
She approached the house next to the pink house, paying no mind to the people gathered outside.
She entered resolutely, without knocking, since for two months in her childhood, it was her home too.
She wore a big smile on her face, planning to salute him as soon as she entered.
Suddenly, she saw Carmella rising to her, spreading her arms to embrace her, saying, oh, my sweet girl, I'm so sorry.
He just passed away in his sleep.
He gave two coughs and then was silent.
There was nothing to be done.
She didn't cry, only felt her legs wouldn't hold her.
She saw Carmela's lips, continuing to move, but heard nothing.
She sank to the floor, her back against the wall, pulling her knees between her arms, rocking slightly back and forth as if trying to wake from a bad dream.
How she loved him, this man who loved her back.
a warm and wise Hungarian who enveloped his children in warmth and briefly her too, always remaining like another father just beyond the fence.
Carmella extended her hands to her.
Get up, child.
He was so proud to see you with the ranks and instructor's cord.
He always said you would be an officer because there's nothing you can't do.
that you know how to navigate life with so much calm and confidence, with such maturity.
He wouldn't want to see you sitting on the floor.
And she got up, hugged their two children, thinking to herself that she lost her mother before she was 16, and they lost Zavik, their father, and they're even younger than she was.
She also thought that if one must die, perhaps it's better this way to simply go to sleep and not wake up without suffering.
How much he would be missed.
